text:
Hi!  Question about freelance.
If a client comes to you suuuper last minute with a few emails and you're turning it around within 24 hours, how would you charge?  I'm used to charging hourly for SEO strategy and writing. So I'm unsure here.

elements.text:
Hi!  Question about freelance.
If a client comes to you suuuper last minute with a few emails and you're turning it around within 24 hours, how would you charge?  I'm used to charging hourly for SEO strategy and writing. So I'm unsure here.

text: My usual rush rate is 30% of the overall project fee. In your case, you can either tack it on after the invoice is generated or create a flat fee of whatever amount you think is appropriate.

elements.text: My usual rush rate is 30% of the overall project fee. In your case, you can either tack it on after the invoice is generated or create a flat fee of whatever amount you think is appropriate.

text: 50%+ of the original quote.

elements.text: 50%+ of the original quote.

text:
So, I'm working on an article for <@UJG9WTEKG> and the Superpath blog all about *what to do in your first 90 days in a new content marketing job.*  I"d love to feature a bunch of tips from people within in this community.

Q: If you started a new job in the last few years, what's one thing you did in the first 3 months that ended up being extremely helpful?

Please don't hesitate to post your reply in a thread or DM me in here.

Thanks all!

text: I can’t wait to read this article! I 1000% agree with <@UJG10LPNG>. I also like to read through some of their most recent, favorite, and best-performing pieces of content. And, then, if I have time, do the same for their least-favorite or least-performing content pieces. This gives me a good idea of their brand and allows me to take notes and ask questions. And this type of work doesn’t generally rely on you to have a a lot of knowledge or onboarding things.

text:
Happy to help!

I started a role last December in a space (edtech for HE) I didn’t know much about. One of the first things I did was ask for _anything_—think: recorded customer calls and/or interviews, support chat logs, customer feedback, survey results, reviews, etc.—that would help me understand a) who the people we’re working for are, b) what language they use to describe their pain points & needs, and c) how our service fits into their lives.

The sooner you understand your audience, the better. Everything else can wait :wink:

text:
i feel trite pitching a book, but this is literally a detailed plan for starting out (sans content marketing angle). I read it before starting my current role and it definitely accelerated my time to producing value for the company <https://www.amazon.com/First-90-Days-Strategies-Expanded/dp/1422188612>

I also agree with <@U017WRJTKF1>, talk to every single person that makes sense. From leadership, to other department roles. Get on every single sales call or meeting they'll let you participate in.

When I've spoken to talent acquisition folks recently, my answer to the "how would you get started in the role?" is this: I have no problem asking lots of dumb questions until I feel like I'm a subject-matter expert in the company.

The side benefit to talking to everyone is you do identify some great content opportunities that would likely go missed without that "newbie" conversation.

elements.text: i feel trite pitching a book, but this is literally a detailed plan for starting out (sans content marketing angle). I read it before starting my current role and it definitely accelerated my time to producing value for the company

The side benefit to talking to everyone is you do identify some great content opportunities that would likely go missed without that "newbie" conversation.

text:
I think the first few months are so important for your long-term success so this is really a great topic.

1: Be curious - consume all the content that was created before you joined, interview the sales team, and talk to a customer.
2: Identify easy wins - what can you repurpose? What is outdated that you can redirect? What can you repackage or bundle to create something new?
3: Figure out what metrics matter to the business - it's going to be different everywhere you go depending on the product/business model. Then, what is the current state of that number?

I think only when you do these three things can you start figuring out the direction you should take content and what gaps you need to fill! Just wrote about this on my personal blog :slightly_smiling_face:

text:
Happy to contribute.

Created content values and market them internally with our people.

This has been instrumental for our company in pre-launch mode. We are a content curation and discovery platform for B2B marketers and we need to be kick ass content creators. Everyone gets it and everyone wants to contribute to our content strategy.

The content values has translated into company values and everyone turns to them when making decisions about their work. It's been pretty special to see take shape...even in a remote setting.

elements.text:

The content values has translated into company values and everyone turns to them when making decisions about their work. It's been pretty special to see take shape...even in a remote setting.

text: I’ve noticed in the last few months when I land on a site after using a question or long-tail search query that Google sometimes highlights in yellow the passage most pertinent to my search and anchors me there. I wonder if things move more that way, perhaps the one big scroll would become more popular.

text:
So looking forward to this article. I just started at a new company so this is very top of mind for me!

My game plan is usually the following:

1. Be a sponge. Work with your onboarding manager and team to help you prioritize where to start digging first, but spend your first week just consuming.
2. Stay curious. I think this is key to building a strong foundation and providing value quickly. You're new, and it's okay not to know what you don't know. Take your time, ask questions, and allow your interests and curiosity to lead the way into your new company / market / role.
3. Meet everyone. Seriously meet everyone you can. At least one person from every department or team, and work with your manager to identify who would be the most helpful in getting you up to speed. You'll learn about your product, company, market, and audience from endless angles in a short amount of time. In each meeting, pay attention to the gaps you can help fill. 
4. Audience, audience, audience. Like a few people have mentioned, start here. Subscribe to publications that are relevant to them, join Slack groups :wink: , follow related-influencers on LinkedIn, Twitter, etc. 
5. After building this foundation, THEN start to map out the gaps and opportunities you've learned. These learnings will help light your path forward. Work backwards from there to create related goals and a plan to meet them

Stay curious. I think this is key to building a strong foundation and providing value quickly. You're new, and it's okay not to know what you don't know. Take your time, ask questions, and allow your interests and curiosity to lead the way into your new company / market / role.

Meet everyone. Seriously meet everyone you can. At least one person from every department or team, and work with your manager to identify who would be the most helpful in getting you up to speed.
